results.title: The Curiosity that kills the cat
results.creator_credit: Cedric Maggs, G. Buckland-Smith and British Films
results.brief_description: Shows the extent to which animals, specially bred for the purpose or imported wild from overseas, are used in medical research, the pharmaceutical industry and the cosmetic industry. Suggests that some of the vast sums of money spent on animal experiments might be devoted to the development of alternative, more humane techniques.

results.title: The Curb between us
results.brief_description: As a result of a car accident, Terry Kelly became a disabled person. After nine months in hospital Terry tries to rebuild his life with family, friends and his studies. Examines questions such as how it feels to be disabled and the prejudices and problems encountered by the disabled.

results.title: The Cuphead Show!
results.brief_description: Follow the misadventures of the impulsive Cuphead and his cautious but persuadable brother Mugman in this animated series based on the hit video game.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Timeless early animation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation traces the inspirations and evolution of the Cuphead animation technique and franchise back to the early 20th century and beyond.

results.title: The Cup that cheers
results.creator_credit: K Khandpur, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The story of the Indian tea industry which gives employment to about one million workers. Illustrates the various processes involved in its cultivation, manufacture, marketing and exports.

results.title: The Cup Final [1966]
results.brief_description: Opens with a dressing room scene before the commencement of play at Wembley of the 1966 FA Cup Final championship between two great English northern teams, Everton and Sheffield Wednesday.

results.title: The Cup Final [1964]
results.brief_description: The British F.A. Cup Final of 1964 between West Ham and Preston North End. Shows highlights of the game which was called “the best final for many a year”. West Ham were the winners, 3-2.

results.title: The Cup
results.creator_credit: Khyentse Norbu, Raymond Steiner, Malcolm Watson, Hanway Films and Palm Pictures
results.brief_description: It is 1998 and World Cup fever has reached as far as a monastery in the Indian Himalayas. Here, young Orgyen and fellow monks are taken with the excitement of the cup final approaching, their only dilemma is how are they going to be able to watch the final without a TV. ‘The Cup’ is a delightful comedy that looks at how a group of novice monks can come up with money to rent a TV and seek the permission of their leader, Geko, who is firm handed, and Khempo, the older and slightly more easy going leader. Written and directed by Khyentse Norbu who was himself a Buddhist monk, this is the first film to be released in the Tibetan language. In Bhutanese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Culture explosion
results.creator_credit: Eric Koch and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A discussion of the position of the arts in the 1960’s, particularly in the U.S.A. and Canada. Speakers such as Jonathan Miller, Peter Ustinov, Elke Sommer and Jean Renoir consider various viewpoints such as artistic standards and values (art as an antidote for the drabness of standardised modern life), popular taste and interest(as a response to the ancient urge to create something of beauty), the business side, patronage and government support, and the place of art in society (the essence of art as being sensual and intuitive and beyond the reach of any “culture explosion”).

results.title: The Cultural Revolution
results.creator_credit: Myra Roper and Melbourne State College. Media Production Centre
results.brief_description: The film contains footage of both city and Peasant Chinese during the Cultural Revolution beginning 1966. Gives some background to the movement and compares Mao’s comment that it was 70% good and 30% bad with a current Chinese assessment that it was a 10 year reversal of the Chinese socialist cause.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Myra Roper and Melbourne State College. Media Production Centre

results.title: The Culinary art of Japan
results.brief_description: Japanese cooking is unique. It is based on seasonal culinary specialities, the preparation and serving of which is considered to be an art. Shows the buying of fresh fish and vegetables, the tea ceremony, a traditional dinner, cooking schools, family meals and the preparation of sukiyaki, tempura and sushi.
